So C has the experience of thinking it's A and not B, and thinking it's B and not A, and maybe independent C thoughts not in A or B.

Another fun issue that I've been dealing with for years, is re-writing songs. When I do go back to try to expand upon old ideas and fragments, I wind up making changes to the original idea and not adding anything new.. q.a: that's when you discover what your singing voice can really do. real life is unscripted. 99.9% of our talking is spent unscripted. it is automatically genuine when you are making it up. the 'weird challenge' is to do scripted material. even the best actors in the world still sometimes sound fake doing this. it is significantly more difficult to find a genuine voice when doing scripted material (spoken or sung) whereas the genuineness is pretty much there by default when you are making it up. for example try reading a book out loud. then compare that to how you normally sound when you are talking to real people throughout your day. you'll see which one is more genuine. unless you happen to be an awesome voice actor in which case maybe the written one might sound totally bang-awesome, but actually still probably fake. unless you've really got the seasoned touch of 1,000 ninjas

q.a:
this is similar to what i went through, because i am working from the same starting point as you. but you will already be better after 1 month. and at 2 months you will be a little better. and at 3 months you will be better. so the 'baseline' you are working with is actually right now, that's your starting point. 2 months from now will be the middle. unless you stop singing entirely after 2 months.
for specifics on technique, for some reason no professional vocal technical advice ever made any sense to me until many years later, and much of it still doesn't. i found that the voice is so deeply connected with life itself that it was almost impossible for me to think directly about most of the things professionals tell you to think about. so i had to find much more abstract tricks. one of the most important tricks i learned was to improvise the lyrics. and for scripted material, try to do it like you are terrified of joe jackson whipping you
q.q:
let's say that i desperately wanna make my own music, just as you are, but i have absolutely no experience in making my voice sound remotely good. i've got good ears and pitch and everything, but the voice just sounds bad and the technique is nonexistent. how do you think i could at least get my voice to a good baseline which i could expand on throughout my life, in like a solid two months?
i know "just do it a lot" is a great answer here, but how do i "just do it" well enough that i can make solid progress along with that? i think i know how this works for physical instruments which i can observe the mechanics of in front of my eyes, but the voice is too obscure, where should i even start? i can feel myself dipping into that 13th level of suffering

q.q: I have basic video editing software that I have been using to make videos for my music.  Problem is, I find the way I use this software to be not unique to me in style.  I use it to layer colors and text and images and such.  I know I am very inspired by you, but I don't know if what I am doing is copying you or just doing what I can with what I have.  It bothers me that the word copycat is being used by some people to describe how your style might be influencing others. But I dont know if it's bothering me because i know i should feel bad about not having an entirely original video aesthetic or if the word just doesnt seem fair to others who are doing their best with tools.   Making the music takes time, making the videos takes time, somehow this way of making videos just feels so intuitive.  Like it's the most effective and efficient way to make content that is of some quality.   I'm not sure how to feel about it.  Would you advise me to steer clear of this way of editing?  I get a bit panicky when I think of turning up the different dial because I dont know how to conceptualize another video style that feels like it has quality to it but doesnt take forever to make (using only my simple tools).  Am I screwed?  Part of me does feel bad because I feel like if I'm good enough I should know what to do about this problem.

i had an anagram-related ethical dilemma yesterday and was wondering what you'd have done in my situation so i have more insight next time something similar happens.

i was recertifying my first aid training for the 1939545th time and i was bored out of my skull, so i took a pen and the little manuals they give you and started writing possible anagrams next to the chapter headers. there were lots of wild ones, but i think "bone, joint, and muscle injuries" ---> "boner juice slut, join me and sin" was my favourite.

but then!!!!! at the end of the course!!!! THEY ASK FOR THE MANUALS BACK. nobody told me that would happen and the manuals have always been ours to keep at every other certification i've ever attended. so it's like, do i return this and never train with the first aid company again (i have very distinctive handwriting that matches the handwriting on my registration form), or covertly try to steal the manual? i tried the latter but a classmate saw and gave me a dirty look so i ended up returning it and shoving it into the middle of the pile. i still don't know whether that was the correct decision.

my worst fear is that the next person reading that manual won't realize the anagrams are in fact anagrams, and will just think i wrote "boner juice slut, join me and sin" over the chapter title for no reason. anyway what would the best course of action have been? do you have any advice for future similar instances of this? thanks

q.a: go through about 50 of your favorite songs, and identify them with brute force. quickly unpause/pause (or nowadays you can edit to loop a tiny fraction of audio very quickly) and just pick it out note by note and put it together. write down all the chords to a song (in time, with bar lines, etc.)..... once you do this for about 30 or 40 songs, i think you will find that you don't have to search for the individual notes anymore. ... maybe not even pause it at all. After about 100 more songs, you probably won't even have to listen to the song, you will be able to do it from memory. after about 1000 songs, you will probably be able to hear someone singing the melody for a song you have never heard before, without hearing the chords, and figure out what the chords should be. after 10,000 songs, you should be able to play along with them on the first try, never having heard the song before, and have them think you already knew the song

q.a: if i'm supposed to record songs on a regular basis, there's no such thing as a creative block. gotta make it happen. if i'm supposed to record a song not on a schedule, then it will probably never get done. if i'm not supposed to record a song, then it will definitely not get done. but the procedure for song selection is, first i do a general writing session to come up with new ideas to add to the list. then i go through the entire list (the list contains everything, finished or non, mostly unfinished actually because if there's anything finished in there it has probably already been picked) and pick out ones that feel like they could be the right choice, that may be a list of about 10 to 20. then i immediately do a random number selection and that's the selection. then i finish the writing, then do it
